title: Syria after Assad, a half-festive, half-worried anarchy: 'You won't believe where I am. We're going home!'
summary: While many Syrians are elated to finally be able to return home, many others have begun fleeing the country. In Damascus, residents waver between fear and subdued euphoria.

title: Syria rebel leader discusses 'transfer of power' after Assad's fall
summary: Rebel leader Abu Mohammed al-Jolani, now using his real name Ahmed al-Sharaa, met with Prime Minister Mohammed al-Jalali 'to coordinate a transfer of power that guarantees the provision of services' to Syria's people, said a statement posted on the rebels' Telegram channels.

title: Historian Matthieu Rey: 'Although there is uncertainty in Syria, a sense of joy is making a widespread comeback'
summary: Ravaged by more than 10 years of fighting, the country is getting back on its feet, and faces immense challenges, explains historian Matthieu Rey, in an article for 'Le Monde.'

title: Monitor says more than 100 Israeli air strikes on military sites in Syria
summary: Israel, which borders Syria, has sent troops into a buffer zone on the east of the Israeli-annexed Golan Heights after Assad's fall, in what Foreign Minister Gideon Saar described as a 'limited and temporary step' for 'security reasons.'

title: TikTok is close to being banned in the US. Its last hope: Donald Trump
summary: A US federal appeals court has just rejected the  platform's appeal against a law that would ban it in the country unless it is sold by its Chinese shareholder. The  president-elect, who has been alternatingly pro- and anti-TikTok,  will determine its fate after his inauguration on January 20, 2025.

title: Man arrested over killing of US health insurance CEO being held without bail
summary: Luigi Mangione, 26, was being held by officers in Pennsylvania after being found with a weapon that police described as a 'ghost gun' capable of firing 9MM rounds and equipped with a suppressor. Mangione must now be extradited from Pennsylvania to New York to face murder charges, police said.

title: Dozens of Nobel laureates sign letter opposing RFK Jr. as Trump's health secretary
summary: Among the signatories is Drew Weissman, who received the 2023 Nobel Prize in Medicine for his work on developing mRNA vaccines, which was a major breakthrough in the fight against Covid-19.

title: Kremlin refuses to confirm if Assad is in Russia
summary: Russian state news agencies had reported that ousted Syrian President Bashar al-Assad and his family had been given asylum. However, Kremlin spokesman Dmitry Peskov declined to confirm these reports.

title: The rise of Abu Mohammed al-Jolani: From jihadist in Iraq to Syria's new strongman
summary: After fighting with Al-Qaeda in Iraq and Syria, the leader of the Islamist armed group Hayat Tahrir al-Sham went on to discipline the Syrian rebels and reassure religious minorities. But his real intentions remain an enigma.

title: Several European countries suspend Syrians' asylum requests
summary: Germany, Sweden, Denmark, and Norway have all frozen decisions on Syrian asylum requests. German Chancellor Olaf Scholz and French President Emmanuel Macron on Monday discussed the possibility of cooperating with Syria's new leaders following the ousting of President Bashar al-Assad, the chancellery said.

title: 'Emilia Perez' leads Golden Globe nominations with 10
summary: After winning at Cannes, Jacques Audiard's musical about a Mexican drug lord who transitions to life as a woman is marching toward more prizes in Los Angeles.

title: Director accused of abusing French actress Adèle Haenel goes on trial
summary: Christophe Ruggia is accused of sexually assaulting the actress in the early 2000s when he directed her in her debut film, when she was between 12 and 14 and he was in his 30s.

title: In Georgia, anger spreads beyond the capital: 'We've never seen such a treacherous government!'
summary: More than 40 towns and villages have joined the protest movement against the government, which has suspended the process of joining the European Union until 2028.

title: Finland's President Stubb: Europe must choose between 'Yalta moment and Helsinki moment'
summary: Finnish President Alexander Stubb says in an interview that Vladimir Putin's Russia must pay a price for its war of aggression against Ukraine.

title: In Assad's fall, the US sees validation of its Middle East strategy
summary: Joe Biden hailed the fall of Bashar al-Assad as a 'moment of historic opportunity.' Voices within both the current administration and among those close to President-elect Donald Trump, have hailed the possibility of lasting damage to Iran and its regional proxies.

title: Bashar al-Assad's downfall is a major setback for Russia
summary: The Syrian president has taken refuge in Moscow. In 2015, Kremlin support enabled him to regain control of a large part of the country. This time, the Russian army, concentrating on the Ukrainian front, has hardly intervened against the Islamist rebels.

title: Fall of Assad: In Germany, Austria and Greece, a jubilant Syrian diaspora cautious about a possible return
summary: Around 5,000 people gathered in Berlin to celebrate the fall of the Syrian regime on Sunday, December 8. There were 10,000 people gathered in Vienna and 1,000 in Athens.

title: Bashar al-Assad's: The 12 days that toppled the Syrian regime
summary: Less than two weeks were enough to put an end to half a century of rule by the Assad dynasty. Although the offensive by the Islamist rebels and their coalition took the regime by surprise, the attack had been prepared for several months and was supported by Turkey.

title: Zelensky says grateful for Trump's 'strong resolve' to end war
summary: French President Emmanuel Macron hosted three-way talks with Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky and US President-elect Trump at the Elysée Palace on Saturday as fears grow in Kyiv about the level of support Ukraine will receive under the incoming US administration.

title: At Louvre-Lens, the Galerie du Temps gets a facelift
summary: Twelve years after its inauguration in the museum in the north of France, the vast space covering 5,000 years of history across different periods has been entirely revamped.

title: Macron calls for cross-party talks to form new government
summary: President Emmanuel Macron invited all parties – bar the far-right Rassemblement National and hard-left La France Insoumise – to new talks on Tuesday, as France looks to form a new government.

title: South Korean president banned from leaving country
summary: President Yoon Suk Yeol has been banned from leaving South Korea days after surviving a parliamentary impeachment motion following a brief imposition of martial law.

title: Mass evacuation of Philippine villages underway after a brief but major volcanic eruption
summary: The eruption of Mount Kanlaon on Negros island has forced the evacuation of thousands as ash and hot debris reign down on a wide area in the central Philippines.

title: South Korean prosecutors seek to arrest ex-defense minister over imposition of martial law
summary: A Korean court is reviewing a request to arrest former Defense Minister Kim Yong Hyun, who has been accused of recommending martial law to President Yoon Suk Yeol and sending troops to the National Assembly to block lawmakers from voting on it.

title: Notre-Dame's reopening, as seen by the foreign press: Trump's 'remarkable comeback,' a 'requiem' for Macron
summary: News organizations unanimously hailed the cathedral's 'miraculous' rebirth, but some criticized the presence of US president-elect Donald Trump, or highlighted the contrast between the pomp of the ceremony and the scale of France's political crisis.

title: In Syria's Saidnaya prison, the shattered hopes of families of the missing
summary: Thousands of people have flocked to the prison since it was liberated, attracted by rumors that there were still prisoners in the compound's basements. On Monday night, rescue workers completed their search, revealing 'no unopened or hidden areas within the facility.'

title: In Haiti, women suffer the consequences of gang violence
summary: As the country continues to sink into a deep political and security crisis, more and more Haitian women are being raped by members of armed groups. Access to healthcare is difficult, and local organizations are overwhelmed.

title: Macron brings party leaders together for talks, excluding RN and LFI
summary: After individual consultations, the president, who has still not appointed a new prime minister, invited party leaders to the Elysée on Tuesday.

title: 'Notre-Dame is a symbol of resistance to global chaos'
summary: Notre-Dame's reopening was a mix of religious, political and diplomatic aspects, each trying to assert their legitimacy in a world in crisis, writes François Mabille, an expert in religion and international politics.

title: Brazilian President Lula undergoes brain hemorrhage surgery
summary: After an October 19 fall, Brazil's Luiz Inacio Lula da Silva was admitted to hospital on Monday, and underwent surgery for a brain hemorrhage, which 'went without complications,' according to the hospital.

title: French telecoms company Orange fined for unsolicited ads
summary: Orange, France's largest internet operator, was fined €50 million by France's privacy watchdog CNIL, for sending its customers unsolicited adverts resembling emails.

title: Israel's PM Netanyahu in court to testify in corruption trial
summary: Benjamin Netanyahu faces charges of bribery, fraud and breach of public trust in three separate cases.

title: Musée Cognacq-Jay in Paris reopens, a few days after a robbery
summary: The Parisian institution claims to have complied with all security standards. The number of in French museuls thefts has been falling since 2023.

title: Europe debates fate of Syrian refugees
summary: Several countries, including France and Germany, have announced that they are suspending decisions on asylum applications from Syria. Far-right parties, meanwhile, have re-opened a political and legal debate on refugee deportation.

title: A mock trial promotes the Seine's rights
summary: A simulation organized by the City of Paris aimed to demonstrate the limits of the current laws in protecting ecosystems.

title: Sudan: Army airstrike on North Darfur market kills more than 100, lawyers' group says
summary: Tens of thousands have been killed and millions displaced in a 20-month war between the RSF and Sudan's regular army.

title: Fine particle pollution blamed for nearly 240,000 EU deaths in 2022
summary: The European Environment Agency stresses that air pollution remains the biggest environmental threat to the health of Europeans.

title: Suez parts ways with CEO Sabrina Soussan
summary: The utility company is restructuring after Veolia acquired two-thirds of its business in 2021.

title: What will France's climate be like at +4°C?
summary: The national weather service has published forecasts on the temperatures and precipitation that the country is likely to experience in 2030, 2050 and 2100. These projections will serve as the basis for the national climate change adaptation plan.

title: Syrian rebels name Mohammed al-Bashir head of transitional government
summary: Mohammed al-Bashir had previously headed the rebels' so-called Salvation Government in northwest Syria.

title: Poland's Tusk says Ukraine peace talks could start this winter
summary: Polish Prime Minister Donald Tusk will speak with Ukraine's President Volodymyr Zelensky later on Tuesday.

title: Argentina rape case against French rugby players dropped
summary: An Argentine court, in the city of Mendoza, Argentina, dismissed rape charges against Hugo Auradou and Oscar Jegou, two French international rugby players. The prosecution had argued for the case to be dropped.

title: Macron aims to name prime minister 'within 48 hours,' say party chiefs
summary: French President Emmanuel Macron met with party leaders on Tuesday for talks on the formation of the new government. The far-right Rassemblement Nationale and radical-left La France Insoumise were not invited.

title: Israel takes advantage of Syrian regime's fall to extend its control of strategic areas
summary: Claiming to aim to guarantee its own security, Israel has deployed troops beyond the UN-monitored buffer zone with Syria. While 'temporary,' according to Israel's Foreign Minister, the move raises several questions.

title: Le Pen and Mélenchon caught out by past support for Bashar al-Assad
summary: In recent years, both French politicians have made supportive remarks about the dictator. Marine Le Pen saw him as a bulwark against jihadism, while Jean-Luc Mélenchon was driven by visceral anti-imperialism aimed at America.

title: Adèle Haenel tells director Christophe Ruggia to 'just shut up' after he denies child abuse in court
summary: The French actress, who quit filmmaking after saying the industry turned a blind eye to sexual abusers, says Christophe Ruggia groomed and assaulted her when she was between 12 and 14.

title: 'The Paris AI summit will act against the risks and for the benefits of AI'
summary: Anne Bouverot is tasked by the Elysée Palace with organizing an AI summit in February bringing together companies, NGOs and 100 heads of state.
